Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, a smile tugging at my lips as I read her message: “Let’s pick a night this week for our date. I miss you.” We’d both been so busy, but finally, our schedules lined up. I could almost hear her laughter, feel the warmth of her hand in mine. I wanted to give her my full attention, to be the boyfriend she deserved—present, caring, and attentive.

But then, another message arrived. This one was from Brother Ahmed, a pillar of our mosque. “Imam, can we meet soon? My family is going through a lot. I really need your guidance.” His words carried a weight I couldn’t ignore. As imam, I was expected to be there for my community, to offer counsel and comfort, especially in times of crisis.

I felt the tension coil in my chest. Both roles demanded my time, my empathy, my presence. I wanted to be there for her, to nurture our relationship. But I also couldn’t turn away from someone in need. My mind raced, torn between love and duty, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left waiting.
